What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: 8h
5h

I truly did not like this class. I was not at all interested in this material. In future, please allow students to pick a SBS class they want. This class was so basic : high school feeling, and the material learned, alas a lot, it felt more like general knowledge. I truly did not enjoy this. I would have preferred to pick one SBS class, for example a class talking about aging, and take a deep dive on this issues. I am very frustrated at the administration for making this class compulsory. What a waste of expensive money. Just take a few topics and learn further about them. Also, the homework assignments were so unnecessary. Most students just read the discussion and came up with lame critic questions. Almost everyone in class were in their laptops doing other work. Please think of other ways to reinforce positive learning. Reading more, and doing more writing does not improve quality of class.
Extremely poor course unfortunately, material is disparate and assignments are busy work rather than helping to instill learning. Please take this course out of the offerings.

While I feel bad criticizing this course, I feel obligated to do so given the numerous, significant issues with it. the professor largely read off of prepared slides in class, and the the in-class discussions were incredibly slow with most students disengaged / on their laptops. Many of the activities given in-class felt like those assigned in high school -- "talk to your neighbor about X." These conversations lacked any sense of depth. Having a quiz at the beginning of class was not helpful. 

Also, the topic areas covered in the course are largely research-focused. Applying these topics to fields outside of academia would be useful for those of us who do not plan on becoming academic researchers. Since many of the topic areas are very very relevant outside of academia, I think this would add a lot to the discussion / usefulness of the class. (Thinking more about how social relationships affect work environments, public health interventions, etc as opposed to discussing how you measure a concept if you're doing research).
good class. Did not feel like I learned a ton but it was a nice discussion course. Would recommend to break up a course schedule for anyone taking strictly quant-based classes.

This course was a great overview of the social and interpersonal influences on health. Though Professor Monin had to take on a lot of different subjects throughout the semester, she somehow managed to make every lecture pretty specific. I liked that we had a lot of discussion time in pairs/small groups. The only thing that would have put this class over the top would have been a final lecture wrapping up the entire semester, given that we covered so many disparate areas.
Great course! Very interesting topics.
interesting topics
The greatest strength of this course was good choice of interesting readings. However, the assignments and participation grade felt like busywork, not tasks that I was gaining a lot from.
Great!
This is a fantastic course, a great overarching exploration of social and interpersonal influences on health.

This class covered a large variety of topics, many of which were personally interesting to me. The assignments were due at inconvenient times, particularly if we were traveling for otherwise engaged for parts of the weekend. I loved the lecture from the Child Life Specialist, I would definitely recommend bringing in more guest speakers or lecturers. There was not a lot of guidance in terms of the review paper, but the instructions and examples made the assignment clear.
The topics are varied but all are easily woven together and cover a variety of interesting and novel concepts

Strengths: classroom discussion, focus on journal publications
Weakness: no tie in of concepts at end of course

Joan is a very nice instructor, helpful and loves her work. 
I just didn't like the class. I would take an advanced class she teaches that focuses on few SBS topics. 
Good professor, just horrible class.

Very unprofessional though seems extremely nice. Could not lead an impartial, academic or professional discussion, and fostered an unengaged and uninspired environment. Too many personal anecdotes and lack of synthesis of topics.

Professor Monin seems like she knows her area of research well and is genuinely interested in the topics. 

A big turn off for me was that the professor made numerous political comments, insinuating that those with certain political opinions (namely conservative) were bad. This normative stance on certain policies made for an environment where only one viewpoint (very, very liberal) was expressed. If someone did hold a differing opinion, they certainly wouldn't have comfortable expressing it. The professor would say things such as, "I found out my neighbor supported a certain political candidate and I stopped wanting to interact with them." I think this is a concern for YSPH in general, as one opinion / voice is becoming the only one heard. Making sure that those with differing (and middle of the road or even slightly conservative!) viewpoints feel comfortable sharing should be prioritized. Many solutions in healthcare will require bipartisan cooperation. Furthermore, equating the worth of a person to their political opinions is strange and uncalled for -- especially in a classroom setting where her voice is elevated as a professor. These types of political comments are more appropriate when you're in the company of family or close friends.
Great Professor. Timely feedback and a nice personality.

Professor Monin is a great lecturer. She created a healthy environment for students to ask questions, but also challenged us to think more critically about our statements. She is also good at allowing for silences, because a lot of professors would not wait around long enough after they ask a question to make sure students speak up.

Professor Monin was very encouraging and supportive of students.  She offered a lot of great topics for those who do not have a heavy sociology/ psychology background and taught them in a very digestible way.
nice and approachable
very nice professor
Great!
The instructor is fabulous. Clearly loves what she does and is an expert on how social and interpersonal relationships affect health. Really enjoyed having the opportunity to learn from her.
Joan was very approachable and easy to talk to. Some of the lectures were a little boring and hard to get through, but some were very engaging and interesting.
Dr. Monin is an excellent Professor, her lectures are informative, while still being interactive and she encourages critical thinking
Creates positive learning environment

The administration need not make this class compulsory. Students should be able to take any sbs elective to fulfill an SBS requirement. Go to first day of class, you will either be ok with it or hate it.
I would not recommend this class to another student. Very poor overall, learned very little
I would not recommend this course to a fellow student. The classroom environment wasn't engaging.
Would recommend as a supplemental course. Won't learn a skill or a well of new knowledge but a nice 5th or 6th class.

This was a great introductory course to the social and interpersonal influences on health. The workload isn't huge, and you get a lot out of the readings. It's great for someone who is drawn to social psychology but doesn't necessarily know exactly what aspect (e.g., dyadic relationships, social media, etc.) is most interesting to him/her.
Amazing course! I highly recommend.  The work load was reasonable and the classes were very interesting.
interesting class. Recommend!
I would not recommend this course to another student. There was very little valuable feedback or assigned work that felt productive.
This is a great introduction to how humans interact in ways that impact health. I definitely recommend this class.

This course covered a broad scope of issues that people face in their community and the effects on their health. The assignments were not extensive but became time-consuming and particularly difficult to complete if there were any conflicts during the weekend or if the end of the week was particularly busy.
Definitely take this class-the topics are very interesting and the lectures are fascinating
Overview of the different social relationships and the impacts each has on an individual's health.
